description.narrative: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets.

activity-description.narrative: To build a network of Country Accelerator Labs as the largest, fastest global learning network on development challenges. The network will surface and reinforce locally sourced solutions at scale, while mobilizing a wide and dynamic partnership of actors contributing knowledge, resources and experie

To build a network of Country Accelerator Labs as the largest, fastest global learning network on development challenges. The network will surface and reinforce locally sourced solutions at scale, while mobilizing a wide and dynamic partnership of actors contributing knowledge, resources and experie

To build a network of Country Accelerator Labs as the largest, fastest global learning network on development challenges. The network will surface and reinforce locally sourced solutions at scale, while mobilizing a wide and dynamic partnership of actors contributing knowledge, resources and experie

condition.narrative: UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative: Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries 1.1 Number of new data sources used at Country Office level: 1.2 Diversity of different data sources used: 1.3 Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented: 1.4 Variety of innovation methods used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses: Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets. 2.1 Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP) 2.2 Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners 2.3 Proportion of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite 2.4 Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning. 3.1 Size and density of the network effects among the Accelerator Labs 3.2 Number of new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network 3.3 Engagement of the broader Development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network 3.4 Amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Networks have on the discourse of the broader Development ecosystem.

comment.narrative:
Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries 1.1 Number of new data sources used at Country Office level: 10 new sources of data per year 1.2 Diversity of different data sources used: 9 different type of data sources per year 1.3 Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented: 50 new potential solutions per lab per year 1.4 Variety of innovation methods used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses: 10 innovation methods per Action Plan
Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets. 2.1 Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP): 8 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2 Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners: At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart. 2.3 Proportion of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite: At least one government entity or partner has learned about Accelerator lab methods. 2.4 Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies: At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects.
Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning. 3.1 Size and density of the network effects among the Accelerator Labs: The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network. 48 interaction per year 3.2 Number of new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network: 50% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3 Engagement of the broader Development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network: Target: The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account.
3.4 Amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Networks have on the discourse of the broader Development ecosystem.
Targets: Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 10 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries 1.1 Number of new data sources used at Country Office level: 2 new sources of data per year 1.2 Diversity of different data sources used: 3 different type of data sources per year 1.3 Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented: 20 new potential solutions per lab per year 1.4 Variety of innovation methods used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses: 2 innovation methods per Action Plan Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets. 2.1 Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP): 3 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2 Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners: At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart. 2.3 Proportion of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite: At least one government entity or partner has learned about Accelerator lab methods. 2.4 Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies: At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects.
Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning. 3.1 Size and density of the network effects among the Accelerator Labs: The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network. 48 interaction per year 3.2 Number of new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network: 5% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3 Engagement of the broader Development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network: Target: The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 2 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account.
3.4 Amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Networks have on the discourse of the broader Development ecosystem.
Targets: Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 2 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries. 1.1 Number of new data sources used at Country Office level. • Crowd sourcing opinions and solutions through social media/ other digital techniques for plastics waste management in Pakistan • Ethnographic/ observational visits to Lahore and Karachi to map plastic waste journey and meet multiple stakeholders
1.2 Diversity of different data sources used • Crowdsourcing data • Interview data • Observation data
1.3 Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented • 5 new potential solutions identified for plastics waste management in Pakistan. • The lab had just began its operations in September. Initial months had been spent operationalizing the lab and planning for launch.
1.4 Variety of innovation methods used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses. • Ethnography • Systems design • Collective Intelligence • Design thinking
Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets. 2.1 Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP) • 3 blogs published in November 2019 • Lab Launch covered. See twitter post of the Lab’s launch: https://twitter.com/UNDP_Pakistan/status/1199550801850572800 2.2 Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners • 100% The main learning portfolio, plastic & circular economy has Unilever has partner. 2.3 Proportion of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite • Conducted a collective intelligence workshop at the digital youth summit 2019 for provincial government Khyber Pakhtunkhwa IT Boardand World Bank that was received well and covered on social media o https://twitter.com/KPDYS/status/1176519158353321984 o https://twitter.com/UNDP_Pakistan/status/1177437076431572992 o https://twitter.com/UNDP_Pakistan/status/1178249390529511426 o https://twitter.com/UNDP_Pakistan/status/1178237851806265344
2.4 Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies • All learning portfolios aim is to produce a proposed and tested portfolio of experiments that are scalable and can be taken up by projects and partners. • Produced intelligence report recommending hypothesis leads for water conservation practices in hotel industry for Development Policy Uniit.s Reccomendatiosn made by conducting a design-thinking workshop.
Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning.
3.2 Number of new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network. • lab participated in multiple checkins with the global Acclab network to design action plans for learning challenges (50% information shared) 3.3 Engagement of the broader Development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network. • Acclab is featured once a month during 2019 (Sep- Dec) • Number of tweets from UNDP’s official account highlighting Lab’s work: 8 • Lab team engages through linkedin. Facebook, Instagram 3.4 Amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Networks have on the discourse of the broader Development ecosystem. • Connected to local development ecosystem through social media i.e. Digital Youth Summit with World Bank • Launch of the Lab also demonstrated the use of collective intelligence and the need to do development differently. • Engaged with Ehsaas program lead and other government minstries during Guilio, Head of RIC visit to Pakistan

Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries 1.1 Number of new data sources used at Country Office level: 5 new sources of data per year 1.2 Diversity of different data sources used: 6 different type of data sources per year 1.3 Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented: 35 new potential solutions per lab per year 1.4 Variety of innovation methods used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses: 5 innovation methods per Action Plan
Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets. 2.1 Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP): 3 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2 Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners: At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart. 2.3 Proportion of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite: At least one government entity or partner has learned about Accelerator lab methods. 2.4 Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies: At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects.
Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning. 3.1 Size and density of the network effects among the Accelerator Labs: The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network. 48 interaction per year 3.2 Number of new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network: 25% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3 Engagement of the broader Development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network: Target: The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account.
3.4 Amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Networks have on the discourse of the broader Development ecosystem.
Targets: Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 5 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries 1.1 Number of new data sources used at Country Office level. • Digital listening- conducting interviews using SMS in Gilgit Baltistan for Social Innovation Platform portfolio (SIP) • Survey results for SIPPS • Social media and digital media analysis to identify trends and patterns of social & economic situation of population groups in Gilgit Baltistan. • Used Collective intelligence to map people perceptions and experience of the current systems I.e. future of work, plastics, rule of law programme • Using Systemic design, ethnographic, current, future state mapping exercise research tools for plastics waste management in Pakistan
1.2 Diversity of different data sources used • Social media data, mobile phone data (IVR, Blast SMS) • Crowd sourcing data • Survey data • Qualitative data – interviews • Ethnography data 1.3 Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented • More than 50 new potential solutions identified for COVID-19 response in Pakistan (Platform link: https://solutionsmapping.wixsite.com/pakistaninnovations ) • 10 new potential solutions identified for plastics waste management in Pakistan link: https://www.pk.undp.org/content/pakistan/en/home/blog/2020/the-good--the-bad-and-the-ugly-of-plastics-in-pakistan.html • Conducted Solutionsfest to identify and protype 10+ solutions for managing plastic waste. • Link: https://undp-pakistan.exposure.co/why-innovation-acclab-pakistan-brought-designers-startups-and-citizens-to-build-solutions-for-plastic-waste
1.4 Variety of innovation methods used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses. • Foresight (stress test), Horizon scanning, Sensemaking, Ethnography, Social Media Analysis, Social Network Analysis, Visual Thinking, Co-creation, Design Sprints/ Innovation challenges, Hackathons, Solutions Mapping, (Community) Asset Mapping, Prototyping, Behavioural Insights, Systems Thinking, Design Thinking, Human Centered Design, Participatory Design, Crowdsourcing, Open Data, Mobile phone data, Portfolio logic, Social Innovation platform approach, Predictive analytics, Sentiment analysis, lanuguage analysis, innovation clinics, systemic design, Collective Intelligence, weak signals of change
Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets. 2.1 Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP) • 10 blogs published in 2020 • 5 Press Releases published & shared with national media, links below: - https://www.pk.undp.org/content/pakistan/en/home/presscenter/pressreleases/2020/prime-minister-of-pakistan-and-undp-commit-to-accelerate-pakista.html - https://www.pk.undp.org/content/pakistan/en/home/presscenter/pressreleases/2020/undp-and-jazz-to-work-together-for-promoting-youth-led-social-in.html - https://www.pk.undp.org/content/pakistan/en/home/presscenter/pressreleases/2020/undp-and-unilever-pakistan-to-work-together-to-make-rahim-yar-kh.html - https://www.pk.undp.org/content/pakistan/en/home/presscenter/pressreleases/2020/president-of-pakistan-and-undp-to-work-together-on-extending-pak.html - https://www.pk.undp.org/content/pakistan/en/home/presscenter/pressreleases/2020/undp-supports-the-national-health-hackathon-for-local-health-car.html
2.2 Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners • 50%. 1 out of 2 learning challenges has private sector onboard. • Plastic portfolio has Unilever as partner. MoU signed. Ministry of Climate Change has expressed interest in the portfolio. • Social Innovation Platform is in initial digital listening phase coordinating with local civil society and UNDP project. Not yet at partnership stage.
2.3 Proportion of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite • Unilever adapted systemic design and portfolio design as a method for future programming. • Ministry of Health and Digital Pakistan adopted behaviour insights
2.4 Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies;
• 100% - All learning portfolios aim is to produce a proposed and tested portfolio of experiments that are scalable and can be taken up by projects and partners. All learning challenges align with CO unit workplans. Systemic work transitioned from insights to a portfolio of experiments for plastics and SIP; o Systemic design workshop held with Unilever on plastic waste, journey mapping and ethnographic mission, solution fest and crowdsourcing on plastic waste has all resulted in developing a portfolio of experiments on plastic waste management with Unilever and anchored with CO project at the Environment Climate Change Unit. Intelligence report produced and portfolio designed and presented. Link: https://www.pk.undp.org/content/pakistan/en/home/blog/2020/untying-a-socially-complex-problem--one-knot-at-a-time.html o Social Innovation Platform portfolio focusing on socio-economic dynamics post-covid in Hushey Valley has produced a proposed portfolio on gastronomy as a result of the deep listening phase. Next stage is to stress-test the portfolio for scale and implementation. Blog published. Link: https://www.pk.undp.org/content/pakistan/en/home/blog/2020/covid-19--why-we-need-to-listen-to-communities-more-than-ever.html • Conducted a horizon-scan and collective intelligence session to explore future of work. Intelligence report for the youth team produced and the findings from these reports eventually translated into developing a green jobs portfolio. Green jobs was proposed as project in the RFF which CO won. Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning. 3.2 Number of new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network. • Lab conducted more than 10 meetings with other AccLabs for sharing portfolio design and systems design work. Lab was also invited twice by regional and global UNDP office for sharing the success of lab’s learning portfolios. (100% information shared) 3.3 Engagement of the broader Development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network. • Acclab is featured more than 4 times each month during 2020. • 41 tweets from UNDP’s official account highlighting Lab’s • Lab team engages through linkedin. Facebook, Instagram. 3.4 Amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Networks have on the discourse of the broader Development ecosystem. • Connected to local development ecosystem through social media i.e. weak signals of change blog was very well taken up by local government partners (Digital Pakistan) • Engaged with more than 10 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem i.e. political champions, startup founders, other ecosystem players

Targets:
Project Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets 2.1 Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP) 2.2 Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners 2.3 Proportion of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite 2.4 Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies
